{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3347914,"name":"Rob Otics","username":"RedStorm509","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/r/7ba0ec/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-03-30T19:09:59.298Z","cooked":"

Team 509 is proud to present our version of the “Chameleon Climber” for the 2024 season. Inspired by team 4087, the design below is our most current, competition ready version.

509Climber528×645 87 KB

One of the focuses of our Climber was to create a modular design that could be easily swapped in and out of our robot for maintenance. The Climber connects to our robots belly pan through 8 1/4-20 bolts. The Climber is also very compact. The base dimensions of the climb are 6” by 9” and it’s only about 11” tall.

One of the ways we’ve been able to keep our climber so compact is with our motor placement. The motor sits right above the spool and is connected to a AndyMark 20:1 CIM Sport gearbox and ratchet which locks to prevent our robot from falling when the game is finished. Actuating the ratchet is a solenoid powered by the REV Pneumatic Hub. By using a solenoid rather than a pneumatic cylinder, we’ve saved space and weight often taken up by air tanks and a compressor.

While we are proud of our climb, there are definitely still aspects that need improvement. One of the challenges we encountered with this climb was the boat hook expanding away from the center spool instead of unfurling vertically. We’ve solved this issue with some 3D printed guides, but bearings or some sort of more permanent solution would definitely be better.

We hope this climb design can serve as an inspiration for other teams to continue to innovate on. Thanks again to team 4087 for the inspiration!

Full Robot CAD: Onshape
Climb CAD: Onshape

Very nice climber! What solenoid are you using for the ratcheting gearbox?

Also, unrelated, but I see for your arm design you have a MAXSpline for your pivot. Attached to it, you have a through-bore hex shaft encoder. In the CAD, it just shows a .5 hex shaft running through the center of the MAXSpline shaft, not connected to anything.

image1468×1128 79.3 KB

I hid the RSL and encoder to see it better. How are you actually attaching these shafts together, or attaching the MAXSpline shaft to the encoder?

Great question, we used a 12V push-pull Solenoid from Adafruit: Large push-pull solenoid : ID 413 : Adafruit Industries, Unique & fun DIY electronics and kits

The MAXSpline to 0.5" hex uses a 3D printed adapter:

image727×761 62.1 KB

I must have forgotten that part as we’ve been making a lot of changes in CAD lately with organization and a new shooter. Thanks for the catch!
